metadata.title: Effects of different nanomaterials on hardening and performance of ultra-high strength concrete (UHSC)

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Cement and Concrete Composites
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate /cemconcomp
Effects of different nanomaterials on hardening and performance of ultra-high strength concrete (UHSC)
Zemei Wu a, b, Caijun Shi a, *, K.H. Khayat b, Shu Wan a
a College of Civil Engineering, Hunan University, Changsha 410082, PR China b Department of Civil, Architectural and Environmental Engineering, Missouri University of Science and Technology, Rolla, MO, USA
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 19 July 2015 Received in revised form 9 January 2016 Accepted 26 March 2016 Available online 29 March 2016
Keywords: UHSC Nano-CaCO3 Nano-SiO2 Hydration Strength Calcium hydroxide Pore structure
* Corresponding author. E-mail address: cshi@hnu.edu.cn (C. Shi).
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cemconcomp.2016.03.003 0958-9465/© 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
Nanomaterials have attracted much interest in cement-based materials during the past decade. In this study, the effects of different nano-CaCO3 and nano-SiO2 contents on flowability, heat of hydration, mechanical properties, phase change, and pore structure of ultra-high strength concrete (UHSC) were investigated. The dosages of nano-CaCO3 were 0, 1.6%, 3.2%, 4.8%, and 6.4%, by the mass of cementitious materials, while the dosages of nano-SiO2 were 0, 0.5%, 1.0%, 1.5%, and 2%. The results indicated that both nano-CaCO3 and nano-SiO2 decreased the flowability and increased the heat of hydration with the increase of their contents. The optimal dosages to enhance compressive and flexural strengths were 1.6% e4.8% for the nano-CaCO3 and 0.5%e1.5% for the nano-SiO2. Although compressive and flexural strengths were comparable for the two nanomaterials after 28 d, their strength development tendencies with age were different. UHSC mixtures with nano-SiO2 showed continuous and sharp increase in strength with age up to 7 d, while those with nano-CaCO3 showed almost constant strength between 3 and 7 d, but sharp increase thereafter. Thermal gravimetry (TG) analysis demonstrated that the calcium hydroxide (CH) content in UHSC samples decreased significantly with the increase of nano-SiO2 content, but remained almost constant for those with nano-CaCO3. Mercury intrusion porosimetry (MIP) results showed that both porosity and critical pore size decreased with the increase of hydration time as well as the increase of nanoparticles content to an optimal threshold, beyond which porosity decreased. The difference between them was that nano-CaCO3 mainly reacted with C3A to form carboaluminates, while nano-SiO2 reacted with Ca(OH)2 to form CeSeH. Both nano-CaCO3 and nano-SiO2 demonstrated nucleation and filling effects and resulted in less porous and more homogeneous structure.
© 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Ultra-high strength cement based-material (UHSC) is a novel type of composite materials with superior static and dynamic mechanical properties, and excellent durability. Such material can be used in marine structures, defense and military engineering applications, and high building construction [1e3]. However, as an intrinsically heterogeneousmaterial, the structure of cement-based materials can be generally discretized into four multi-scale phases: nano, micro, meso, andmacro [4]. Themacro-properties of cementbased materials are dominated by the structure at the nano-scale level. The main hydration product, CeSeH, occupies at least 60e70% by volume of the hardened cement paste. It is a nano-scale
material with average diameter around 10 nm [5]. It is suggested that CeSeH has low, high, and ultra-high density forms with different hardness and elastic modulus values and volume fractions [4,6]. High density CeSeH degrades much slower than low density CeSeH under external environmental condition [6]. Furthermore, water loss from pores in the CeSeH gel can lead to considerable autogeneous shrinkage, which can cause cracking and loss in strength and durability of UHSC [7]. Therefore, it is vital to optimize the microstructure of cement-based materials from the nano-scale to ensure high performance.
Nanotechnology has attracted much interest over the past decade. Since the introduction of nanomaterials, extensive research has been conducted to promote their use in cement-basedmaterial. It is well known that nanomaterials can provide significant enhancement in performance of cement-based material given their physical effect (filling and nucleation effects) as well as the chemical reactivity [8]. Nano-silica (nano-SiO2) [9], nano-alumina (nano-
Al2O3) [10], nano-titanium oxide (nano-TiO2) [11], nano-CaCO3 [12], nano iron (Fe2O3), and nanotubes [13] have been studied for use in cement-based materials. Among those, nano-CaCO3 and nano-SiO2 are commonly used. This is because nano-CaCO3 is relatively cheap due to abundant supplying of CaCO3 in limestone, chalk, and marble, and nano-SiO2 can present superior performance given its high specific area and pozzolanic activity [14]. Prototypes of limestone and silica fume have been employed in cement-based materials for many years [15e17].
Camiletti et al. [14] investigated the effects of nano- and microlimestone on early age properties of ultra-high performance concrete (UHPC) and found that the addition of nano- and microlimestone reduced its setting time. Moreover, the addition of 2.5%e5% nano-limestone could lead to 32%e75% improvement in 24 h compressive strength in comparison to that without any nanolimestone. Shaikh et al. [12] found that samples incorporating 1% nano-CaCO3 particles showed the highest compressive strength for high volume fly ash concrete. Rong et al. [18] found that nano-SiO2 accelerated the hardening and enhanced mechanical properties of UHPC when 3% nano-SiO2, by mass of cementations materials, was incorporated. Ghafari et al. [19] reported that nano-SiO2 reduced the workability of UHPC and increased the compressive strength, especially at early age. Although both the nano-CaCO3 and nanoSiO2 could improve mechanical properties, their hydration mechanisms, hardening processes, and age dependencies are different [20]. This could lead to different hydration products and thereby change inmechanical properties [21e23]. Furthermore, mechanical stirring and ultrasonic dispersion techniques are often adopted to avoid agglomeration of nanomaterials [24]. However, the dispersion time and speed would contribute to the experimental results, which are often neglected. If nanomaterials can be efficiently dispersed under normal mixing procedure, this would not only facilitate their applications in cement-based materials but also reduce energy consumption.
In order to understand the hydration mechanism and hardening process of UHSC made with either nano-CaCO3 or nano-SiO2, the flowability, heat of hydration as well as compressive and flexural strengths of UHSC mixtures with five different contents of each nanomaterial were investigated. The crystalline phases and pore structure of the samples were investigated by thermal gravimetry (TG) and mercury intrusion porosimetry (MIP), respectively. The study seeks to understand the hydration mechanisms of these types and contents of nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text:
Portland cement complying with the Chinese Standard GB1752007 was used [25]. The 3-d compressive and flexural strengths of standard mortar sample are 28.3 and 5.6 MPa, respectively. Silica fume with particle size ranging between 0.02 and 0.28 mm was used. Nano-CaCO3 and nano-SiO2 were used, as shown in Fig. 1. The nano-CaCO3 has a size of about 15e105 nm with 97.8% calcite content. The nano-SiO2 has a size of 5e35 nm with 99.8% SiO2 content. Table 1 summarizes the chemical composition and physical properties of the cementitious materials.
Natural river sand with a fineness modulus of 3.0 was used. Particles with size greater than 2.36 mm were removed by sieving in order to enhance mechanical properties of the UHSC.
A polycarboxylate-based superplasticizer (SP) with a solid content of 20% was incorporated. Its water-reducing capacity is greater than 30%. The dosage of SP in the all mixture was set to 2%, by mass of cementitious materials. This dosage corresponds to a well-dispersed system for the referencemixture without any nano-
material [27,28].

sections.heading: 2.2. Mixture proportion and sample preparation
sections.text: The mixture proportion of UHSC is shown in Table 2. The NC series incorporating 0, 1.6%, 3.2%, 4.8%, and 6.4% nano-CaCO3, by mass of cementitious material were designated as NC0, NC1.6, NC3.2, NC4.8, and NC6.4, respectively. The NS series incorporating 0, 0.5%, 1.0%, 1.5%, and 2.0% nano-SiO2 were referred to as NS0, NS0.5, NS1.0, NS1.5, and NS2.0, respectively. The mixing and curing procedure is shown in Fig. 2.

sections.heading: 2.3.1. Flowability
sections.text: The fresh UHSC mixtures were used to cast into a conical mold in the form of a frustum, as described in Chinese Standard GB24192005 [29]. The mini cone has an upper diameter of 70 mm, a lower diameter of 100 mm, and a height of 60 mm. After cone removed, the fresh UHSC mixtures were subjected to 25 jolting cycles on the flow table. Two diameters perpendicular to each other were determined. The mean values of two measurements were recorded as the mini slump flow.

sections.heading: 2.3.2. Compressive and flexural strengths testing
sections.text: Specimens with a size of 40 40 160 mm were used for compressive and flexural strengths testing. Initially, three-point bending testing was conducted to obtain flexural strength. Three samples for each batch were tested. The six broken specimens were then used for compressive testing. The mean values were reported.

sections.heading: 2.3.3. Heat evolution measurement
sections.text: To evaluate the effects of nano-CaCO3 and nano-SiO2 on the hydration rate of UHSC, A TAM air isothermal calorimeter was used tomeasure heat of hydration of cement paste. Based on themixture proportion and sample preparation as described above, the cementitious material, water, and SP were used to prepare the paste. Approximately 4 g paste were weighed and then injected into a glass ampoule using a syringe. The glass ampoule was sealed and then placed into the isothermal calorimeter for 3 d. This equipment consists of a twin-instrument with one sample and one reference. The calorimeter was set to a temperature of 20 C.

sections.heading: 2.3.4. Thermal gravimetry (TG)/Derivative thermal gravimetry (DTG) analyses
sections.text: TG/DTG analyses were used to quantitatively determine the hydration products using a Netzsch STA 409 PC equipment. The tested powder samples, weighing up to 10 mg, were heated from 0 to 1000 C in a nitrogen atmosphere at a heating rate of 10 C/min. The proportion of CH to the residual mass at 1000 C was then calculated.

sections.heading: 2.3.5. Pore structure measurement
sections.text: Mercury intrusion porosimetry (MIP) is based on the principle that mercury, a typical non-wetting liquid, can only intrude a porous material if a certain pressure is applied on the measured samples. The samples were broken into 3.5e5.0 mm pieces and soaked in acetone to stop further hydration. Then they were dried at 60 C in oven for 24 h before examination. The experiments were carried out under low pressure of 0.28 MPa and high pressure of 413.70 MPa, respectively. A glass tube with the specimen and mercury in was subsequently placed in a low and high pressure analysis port. Full-scan auto mode was selected with contacted angle and surface tension of 140 and 480 mN/m, respectively. The intrusion mercury volume was recorded at each pressure point.

sections.heading: 3.1. Effects of nano-CaCO3 and nano-SiO2 contents on flowability of UHSC
sections.text:
The effects of nano-CaCO3 and nano-SiO2 contents on mini
slump flow of UHSC mixtures are illustrated in Fig. 3. It can be seen that the slump flow gradually decreased with the increase of nanoCaCO3 and nano-SiO2 contents. The mini slump flow of the control mixture (NC0) was 220 mm. It decreased to 160 and 155 mm, respectively, when either 6.4% nano-CaCO3 or 2% nano-SiO2 was incorporated. This indicated that the addition of nanomaterials had a significant effect on the required water demand of UHSC mixtures. In addition, the flowability for NC series was more favorable than that of NS series at the same dosage. The mini slump flow of the NC6.4 mixture was equivalent to that of the NS2.0 mixture. This might be attributed to different particle size and specific area. Nano-CaCO3 possessed an average size of about 60 nm and surface area of 4.2 104 m2/kg, while the corresponding values for nanoSiO2 were 20 nm and 1.6 105 m2/kg, respectively. It is well known that the water demand of cement-based materials mainly includes two aspects: (1) filling water in the pore space between the particles; (2) adsorbed water on the surface of particle [30]. Although nanomaterials can fill voids between cement particles to replace some of entrapped water, consequently increase the amount of free water. More free water and superplasticizer would be adsorbed onto the surface of nanomaterials due to their high surface area, leading to decreased free water content and thus increasing the water demand. The latter one is the dominated factor for the decrease of flowability.

sections.heading: 3.2. Effects of nano-CaCO3 and nano-SiO2 contents on heat evolution rate of cementitious materials
sections.text:
Fig. 4 shows the effects of nano-CaCO3 and nano-SiO2 contents
on the heat evolution rate of cementitious materials in UHSC. The addition of nanomaterials not only shortened the dormant period but also lead to an early appearance of the second peak. As seen in Fig. 4(a), the dormant period of the NC0 mixture was around 13 h, the addition of nano-CaCO3 reduced it to about 9 h. This can be considered as a result of filling and chemical effects induced by nano-CaCO3 [31]. Due to its small size, nano-CaCO3 particles act as nucleation seeds. When in contact with water, the Ca2þ that rapidly released from C3S particles is absorbed onto the surface of nano-CaCO3 particles. This would decrease the concentration of Ca2þ around C3S and consequently increase the rate and amount of hydration. Besides, CO32 can react with C3A to form carboaluminates. Carboaluminates is a substance with high permeability in fresh state, which makes ions and water diffuse into internal structure more easily, so as to reduce the concentration of Ca2þ, and thus accelerating the hydration rate [32]. However, it should be noted that the NC4.8 mixture had an earlier and higher heat of hydration than that of the NC6.4 mixture. This might be due to dilution effect associated with nano-CaCO3 when it was used as a substitution of cement. Camiletti et al. [14] reported that replacing cement with nano/micro-CaCO3 can induce a cement dilution effect in addition to a filling and a nucleation effect. When increasing the micro-CaCO3 content to a certain content, the dilution effect could dominate the interaction. This can reduce the heat of hydration, leading to a longer setting time. For nano-SiO2, except its filling effect, it can function as nucleation seeds for the precipitation of CeSeH. This accelerating effect is well reported in publication [9].

sections.heading: 3.3. Effects of nano-CaCO3 and nano-SiO2 contents on compressive and flexural strengths of UHSC
sections.text:
The influence of nano-CaCO3 on compressive and flexural strengths of UHSC at different ages is shown in Fig. 5. It can be observed that there existed an optimal dosage for the strength of UHSC.When thedosageofnano-CaCO3 contentwas in the range from 1.6% to 4.8%, the compressive and flexural strengths were 13%e20% and 15%e30%, respectively, greater than those of the control sample (NC0). However, when the dosage was increased further to 6.4%, the strengths decreased significantly. Inmost cases, the compressive and flexural strengthsof theNC6.4wereeven lower thanthoseof theNC0. For example, the compressive and flexural strengths of the NC6.4 were 113 and 20.9MPa at 91 d,while the corresponding strengths for theNC0were 120 and 22MPa, respectively. Limestone can reactwith C3A to form mono-carbonate, which is a substance with special framework with strong hydrogen bonds between oxygen atoms and interlayer waters in carbonate groups [33]. It is also said that CaCO3 could affect the nature and stability of the AFm phase [34]. However, higher nano-CaCO3 content (6.4%) showed negative effect on strengths of UHSC. This could be attributed to the unsufficient available space for hydration products to form. Also, the superabundant amount of nano-CaCO3 would result in difficulty in uniform dispersion. Weerdt et al. [32] claimed that 5% limestone powder, by mass of total cementious material, had a beneficial effect on the compressive strength of conventional concrete.
Fig. 5 also shows that the compressive and flexural strengths of the NC series increased with age. The compressive and flexural strengths of UHSC samples were around 40 and 9 MPa at 1 d,
ontents on heat evolution rate of UHSC.
respectively. They increased by 120% and 78%, respectively, between 1 and 3 d. The strengths remained almost unchangeable at 7 d. However, a significant increase of 35% and 47% for compressive and flexural strengths were observed between 7 and 28 d. After 28 d, the compressive and flexural strengths were almost constant.
Fig. 6 depicts the compressive and flexural strengths of UHSC with different nano-SiO2 contents. It is obvious that like NC series, NS series also existed an optimal dosage, which was in the range of 0.5%e1.5%. UHSC mixtures with those dosages of nano-SiO2 increased the compressive and flexural strengths by 5e15 and 1e3 MPa, respectively, when compared to the reference samples. This was comparable to the results reported by Rong et al. [18], who adopted sonication to prepared ultra-high performance cementitious composites (w/b ¼ 0.2) with addition of 1%, 3%, and 5% nanoSiO2. However, superfluous nano-SiO2 content of 2% reduced the strengths to a certain value even lower than those of the reference sample. This was associated with the introduction of pores caused by agglomeration of nano-SiO2 and reduced followability of the mixture at high nano-SiO2 concentration [19,40]. Therefore, appropriate addition of nano-SiO2 particles can be well dispersed by using normal mixing procedure in this study.
Compared with the NC series, UHSC mixtures with nano-SiO2 showed higher strengths than that with nano-CaCO3 did at 1, 3, and 7 d. The compressive and flexural strengths were 85 and 16MPa for the NC series, while 100 and 21MPa for the NS series at 7 d. Besides, the strengths increase was about 10% only for the NS series, whereas 30%e50% for the NC series between 7 d and 28 d. However, their strengths were comparable at 28 and 91 d.
Fig. 6. Effect of different nano-SiO2 contents on

sections.heading: 3.4. TG/DTG analysis
sections.text:
Fig. 7 shows the TG and DTG curves of UHSC mixtures with different nano-CaCO3 contents at 28 d. The hydration products in the hardened concrete are calcium silicate hydrate (CeSeH) with endothemal peak at approximately 80e90 C, ettringite with endothemal peak around 130 C, calcium hydroxide (CH) with an endothemal peak in the range of 450e550 C, and calcium carbonate with endothemal peak in the range of 600e700 C. The endothermal peaks at the four temperature ranges are due to the dehydration of CeSeH and ettringite, decomposition of CH and CaCO3, respectively. It can be seen from Fig. 7(b), at the first temperature range of 50e150 C, not only the endothermal peak intensity but also the covered range increased with the increase of nano-CaCO3 content. At 450e550 C, there was no obvious change for the samples with and without nano-CaCO3. As the temperature increased to 600e700 C, the decomposition of CaCO3 increased with the increase of nano-CaCO3 content, which suggested a larger amount of nano-CaCO3 acted as filler in UHSC. It should be noted the curve change for UHSC with high dosage of nano-CaCO3 (4.8%e 6.4%) was smoother than with low dosage of nano-CaCO3. This might be attributed to the sufficient and/or well-crystallized CaCO3 from incorporated nano-CaCO3 particles.
Fig. 8 shows the TG and DTG curves of the NC3.2 at 1, 3, 7, and 28 d. No significant difference between the DTG curves for UHSC samples can be found at 1, 3, and 7 d. All mixtures exhibited a strong AFt peak at 130 C without obvious CeSeH peak. However, when the age reached to 28 d, significant peakwith strong intensity corresponding to CeSeH appeared. Moreover, the intensity of endothermal peak of CaCO3 decreased. This suggested increased
compressive and flexural strengths of UHSC.
CeSeH content and decreased CaCO3 content as curing age prolonged to 28 d. It was indicated that in the presence of CaCO3, mono-carbonate and/or hemi-carbonate could be formed through reacting with C3A. Limestone could also interact with the AFm and AFt phases. Weerdt et al. [21] stated that when limestone was incorporated, a peak of mono-carbonate (MC) or hemi-carbonate (HC) would appear at around 175 C. This agrees well with that significant strength increase between 7 and 28 d. The formation of CeSeH may be first due to the pozzolannic reaction between silica fume and CH. The incorporation of nano-CaCO3 could combinewith CeSeH to form a new compound with space network structure, optimizing the internal structure and consequently improving the mechanical properties of cement-based materials [26].
Fig. 9 shows the TG and DTG curves of UHSC mixtures with different nano-SiO2 contents at 28 d. It can be seen that all the five UHSC mixtures had three significant peaks at around 80, 110, and 150 C. The CeSeH contains absorbed water as well as interlayer water with different endothermal peaks. The first peak corresponds to the dehydration of 1.4 nm tobermorite, which is in the range of 80e90 C. The second peak corresponds to the dehydration of 1.1 nm tobermorite at around 135e150 C [35]. The two effects are caused by the removal of loosely bond water and firmly held water from CeSeH gel, respectively. It has indicated that 1.4 nm tobermorite has a single chain structure of silicate anion, while 1.1 nm tobermorite has a structure of silicate anion with a double chain [36]. The latter is favorable for the strength of cement-based materials. As can be seen from Fig. 9(b), in the range of 30e200 C, the surrounded area of samples with high nano-SiO2 content was broader than that with low content. Besides, the CH content
presented a decreasing tendency with increasing nano-SiO2 content. All these were good implication of pozzolannic reaction between CH and nano-SiO2.
Fig. 10 presents the TG and DTG curves of the NS1.0 at age of 1, 3, 7, and 28 d. As it can be seen, the intensity of CeSeH peak at 135e150 C increased obviously from 1 to 3 d, indicating accelerated hydration rate derived from the pozzolanic reaction. At 28 d, the intensity of CeSeHpeak at 135e150 Cwas almost equal to that at 80e90 C. This suggested optimization of CeSeH structure with curing time. Besides, it can be also found that the peak in the range of 600e730 C on DTG curves was irregular. This suggested that the formed CaCO3 in UHSC containing nano-SiO2 is poor crystallized one, which may be originated from carbonation of hydration products during samples preparation.

sections.heading: 3.5. CH content
sections.text:
The determination of the CH content in concrete samples is an effective method to follow the degree of hydration as a function of time. Fig. 11 compares the relative amounts of CH formed in the NC and NS series with age. It can be seen that the CH content in both NC and NS series decreased with age. The CH content in UHSC samples at 1, 3, and 7 d was hardly changed, however, it decreased significantly from 7 to 28 d. Besides, it is apparent that the general trend of the curves for UHSC with different nano-CaCO3 contents was different from that with nano-SiO2. The CH content in the NC series was not significantly changed with the increased nanoCaCO3 content. On the other hand, a remarkable decrease in the CH content for the NS series was observed. This reflects the different
hydration mechanisms of the nano-CaCO3 and nano-SiO2. In the NS series, the main hydration reaction that correlates to nano-SiO2 is pozzolanic reactionwith CH, as shown in Eq. (1). In NC series, nano-CaCO3 mainly reacts with C3A to form carboaluminates, as shown in Eqs. (2) and (3). Several researchers have demonstrated that limestone does not show pozzolanic properties to produce CeSeH gel [22]. This corresponds to the limited change of CH in UHSC samples made with different nano-CaCO3 contents. However, the incorporation of nano-CaCO3 can change the CeSeH structure, such as the Ca/Si ratio, and thus affecting mechanical properties of UHSC sample [37].
xSiO2 þ yH2O þ zCa(OH)2 / CeSeH (1)
CaCO3 þ 11H2O þ 3CaO$Al2O3 / 3CaO$Al2O3$CaCO3$11H2O (2)
0.5CaCO3 þ 11.5H2O þ 3CaO$Al2O3 þ 0.5Ca(OH)2 / 3.5CaO$Al2O3$0.5CaCO3$12H2O (3)
Another phenomenon that can be seen from Fig. 11 is that the CH content in the NS series was lower than that in the NC series before 7 d, but it was comparable at 28 d. The addition of 20% silica fume seems to be sufficient for the pozzolanic reaction in UHSC. However, the incorporation of nano-SiO2 can alter the consumption rate of CH to form CeSeH due to its much greater specific surface (160,000 m2/kg) than that of silica fume. Moreover, nano-SiO2 has many unsaturated bonds of ^SieOe and ^Sie on the surface.
These would lead to different hydration reaction, as follows [38]: For silica fume,
^SieOeSi^ þ HeOH / ^SieOH (react slowly) (4)
^SieOH þ Ca(OH)2 / CeSeH (5)
For nano-SiO2,
^SieOe þ HeOH / ^SieOH (react quickly) (6)
^Sie þ OHe / ^SieOH (react quickly) (7)
^SieOH þ Ca(OH)2 / CeSeH (8)
The reaction rate for silica fume at the first step (Eq. (4)) is slower than that (Eq. (6)) for nano-SiO2 [39]. Therefore, nano-SiO2 can accelerate the hydration and hardening process of UHSC.

sections.heading: 3.6. Pore structure
sections.text:
Fig. 12 shows the porosity and pore size distribution of UHSC containing different nano-CaCO3 contents at 28 d. It can be seen from Fig. 12(a), within a specified dosage of 3.2%, the total porosity decreased with the increase of nano-CaCO3 content. With further increase in dosage, the porosity began to increase. When the nanoCaCO3 content increased from 0 to 3.2%, the porosity decreased from 15.2% to 12.5%. However, with the nano-CaCO3 content increased further from 3.2% to 6.4%, the porosity increased from 12.5% to 17.5%. Although nano-CaCO3 can efficiently fill internal pores of the hydrated cement paste, high content of such nanoparticles can lead to agglomeration and reduction in flowability and increase in viscosity [39].
For the pore size distribution shown in Fig. 12(b), the dv/dlog (d) curves of the five UHSC mixtures were superposed covering pore size from 40 to 1000 nm. For pore size smaller than 40 nm, the curves for UHSC containing nano-CaCO3 shifted to left indicating finer pores when compared to the NC0 reference sample without any nano-CaCO3. Furthermore, the peak value, i.e. inflection point on the dv/dlog (d) curve, corresponding to critical pore size decreased. This peak value corresponds to capillary pores, which has great influence on the permeability of concrete [40]. It also reflects the connectivity of the pores and tortuosity of penetration path in concrete. The results indicated that the addition of appropriate nano-CaCO3 efficiently reduce the porosity, refine the pores, and thus making UHSC denser and more homogeneous.
Fig. 13 shows the effect of age on porosity and pore size distribution of UHSC containing 3.2% nano-CaCO3. It can be observed
from Fig. 13(a) that the total porosity decreased with age due to continued hydration. The NC3.2 at 28 d had a slightly larger total porosity than those at 3 and 7 d. This may be due to the increased volume of pores larger than 5 mm, as presented in Fig. 13(b). It can be also observed that the peak value on dv/dlog (d) curve reduced gradually with age. The valuewas 0.08ml/g with diameter of 30 nm at 1 d. At 7 d, it reduced to 0.06 ml/g. With age prolonged to 28 d, it reduced further and shifted to finer pores with diameter of 10 nm only. This corresponds well with the results of considerable increase in strength.
In order to further analyze the MIP results, the pores can be classified into five categories, including gel micro-pores (<10 nm), meso-pores (10e50 nm), middle capillary pores (50e100 nm), large capillary pores (100e5000 nm), andmacro-pores (>5000 nm) [41,42]. These values are summarized in Table 3. It can be seen that the volume fractions of meso-pores and middle capillary pores in UHSC containing nano-CaCO3 were lower than that in the NC0 reference sample. The total fraction volume of capillary pores in UHSC samples containing nano-CaCO3 was less than 10%, and the volume fraction of middle capillary pores was close to zero regardless of age. Moreover, the gel micro-pores became the dominated pores, a 150% volume fraction enhancement can be obtained at 28 d when compared to that without nano-CaCO3.
It can be also noted that the fraction volume of large capillary pores decreased with age. This indicated the incorporation of nanoCaCO3 makes the microstructure of UHSC denser and more homogeneous. The pore volume of macro-pores seems to take up a relatively large proportion in all mixtures. This may be due to the large pore size of entrapped air and/or entrained air.
Fig. 14 shows the effects of nano-SiO2 content on porosity and pore size distribution of UHSC at 1 d. Like the NC series, the total porosity of the NS series decreased with the increase of nano-SiO2 content within a specified dosage of 1.0%. However, as the nanoSiO2 content increased further, the porosity increased. For example, when the nano-SiO2 content increased from 0 to 1.0%, the porosity decreased from 18% to 13.5%. When the nano-SiO2 content increased from 1.0% to 2.0%, the porosity increased from 13.5% to 15%. This might be due to the reduced flowability corresponding to higher nano-SiO2 content. From Fig. 14(b), it can also be seen that the peak shifted left with incorporation of nano-SiO2.
Fig. 15 illustrates the porosity and pore size distribution of UHSC containing nano-SiO2 in terms of age. Due to continued hydration, the total porosity decreased with time but was limited, as shown in Fig. 14(a). It can be seen from Fig. 14(b), the peak values on the dv/ dlog (d) curve of NS1.0 at 1 and 3 d was as high as 0.075 ml/g, and decreased to 0.045 and 0.25 ml/g at 7 and 28 d, respectively. Moreover, the critical pore size continuously decreased with the increase of curing age. The corresponding sizes were 30, 20, 15, and
y and pore size distribution of UHSC at 28 d.
Table 4 Pore structure characteristics of UHSC with nano-SiO2.
NS series Total porosity (%) Pore size distribution (%)

10 nm, respectively. This suggested that pores were gradually refined with hydration time.
Table 4 shows the pore size distribution of UHSC containing nano-SiO2. It can be observed that different from NC series, the NS series at 1 d had a large amount of meso-pores up to 60%e70% of the total porosity. This mainly depends on their own characteristics such as, size and chemical reactivity. Nano-SiO2 mainly played its role of pozzolanic reaction at early age, while nano-CaCO3 filled the pores that is close to its own particle size. With the increase of age, the meso-pores remarkable decreased and the gel pores increased, which suggested increased CeSeH content and refined microstructure. In addition, the NS1.0 had a large proportion of macropores at 28 d. If nanomaterials cannot be well dispersed, problem associated with aggregation could result in weak zone in the form of voids.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
Based on the results presented in this study, the following conclusions can be drawn:
(1) Both the nano-CaCO3 and nano-SiO2 decreased the flowability and accelerated the heat of hydration of UHSC. The addition of nanomaterials not only shortened the dormant period but also lead to an early appearance of the second peak. For the same content, the use of nano-CaCO3 resulted in greater flowability compared to nano-SiO2. (2) The optimal dosages for nano-CaCO3 and nano-SiO2 were 1.6%e4.8% and 0.5%e1.5%, respectively. If excessive content was added, the strengths were even smaller than that of the reference samples due to agglomeration problem. The nanoSiO2mainly contributed to the early strength development of UHSC before 7 d, while the nano-CaCO3 led to significant strength increase between 7 and 28 d. However, comparable compressive and flexural strengths of 120 and 23 MPa could be obtained at 28 and 91 d, respectively. (3) From the TG/DTG results, the CH content in UHSC series dropped significantly with the increase of nano-SiO2 content, but remained almost unchanged for the nano-CaCO3 system. MIP results showed that the porosity and the critical pore size decreased with the increase of hydration time as well as the increase of nanoparticles content to an optimal threshold, beyond which porosity decreased. Both nanoCaCO3 and nano-SiO2 demonstrated nucleation and filling effects and resulted in less porous and more homogeneous structure.

metadata.abstractText: Nanomaterials have attracted much interest in cement-based materials during the past decade. In this study, the effects of different nano-CaCO3 and nano-SiO2 contents on flowability, heat of hydration, mechanical properties, phase change, and pore structure of ultra-high strength concrete (UHSC) were investigated. The dosages of nano-CaCO3 were 0, 1.6%, 3.2%, 4.8%, and 6.4%, by the mass of cementitious materials, while the dosages of nano-SiO2 were 0, 0.5%, 1.0%, 1.5%, and 2%. The results indicated that both nano-CaCO3 and nano-SiO2 decreased the flowability and increased the heat of hydration with the increase of their contents. The optimal dosages to enhance compressive and flexural strengths were 1.6% e4.8% for the nano-CaCO3 and 0.5%e1.5% for the nano-SiO2. Although compressive and flexural strengths were comparable for the two nanomaterials after 28 d, their strength development tendencies with age were different. UHSC mixtures with nano-SiO2 showed continuous and sharp increase in strength with age up to 7 d, while those with nano-CaCO3 showed almost constant strength between 3 and 7 d, but sharp increase thereafter. Thermal gravimetry (TG) analysis demonstrated that the calcium hydroxide (CH) content in UHSC samples decreased significantly with the increase of nano-SiO2 content, but remained almost constant for those with nano-CaCO3. Mercury intrusion porosimetry (MIP) results showed that both porosity and critical pore size decreased with the increase of hydration time as well as the increase of nanoparticles content to an optimal threshold, beyond which porosity decreased. The difference between them was that nano-CaCO3 mainly reacted with C3A to form carboaluminates, while nano-SiO2 reacted with Ca(OH)2 to form CeSeH. Both nano-CaCO3 and nano-SiO2 demonstrated nucleation and filling effects and resulted in less porous and more homogeneous structure. © 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
